replies.context: It is very exciting, especially after such a long wait.

Sorry, but there are two things on which you need calibration (literally).
1) To only use the dollar amounts of the telescope project and the annual military budget (and I assume that is what you did) is a bit simplistic.
2) "...unlimited money to destroy things...' paints the picture that it's your opinion that all the military is good for is destruction. I think that is horribly wrong-headed. Does someone really need to explain that? I hope not.

(BTW, I am NOT one of those who say it's a waste to spend on space exploration. But your post belies your disdain for those who protect US interests around the globe (a statement to which you will likely take exception - I hope not, however).

Believing in things for me means there is always a purpose and reason for all things. Nothing is by chance and all things have something that ties them together. Cause and effect, with a Creator behind all of it. If there was an event anything like a "big bang", it would have been an ordered event, not something that just happened when the conditions were right. In that, it would mean their is an intelligence at work, in and through all of it. I know this may be hard to grasp if you do not believe in a power that is over all things, that brings order to what would otherwise be chaos or nothing at all. I hope this somehow fits into something understandable for you. If not, there really isn't much more I can tell you that would change your understanding.

That's funny.  It was a Catholic priest who first came up with the big bang theory, and Einstein rejected it at first because he thought it sounded too much like Bible creationism dogma.  Where do you get the idea that belief in a creator disallows a big bang?
There is no agreement or disagreement. You are wrong. End of story. Now go away.

Science is not a belief system? It certainly as something to do with belief of some sort.

I guess, maybe not 'system of belief'? I'm not sure.

How is science not a belief system or something or other to do with believing something(s)?

In faith I have beliefs about God and Christ that are unwavering.
In science, which is a dynamic process, accepted truths waver all the time. The more we probe our world and our universe, the more we learn and adjust what we thought we knew.
People ask me if I 'believe' in biological evolution, and I say "no." I am quite certain that biological evolution is true, but if new evidence came along to disprove it, then I'd have to accept that I shouldn't have been so certain.

But people 'believe in' Science itself, in the idea, or belief, that humanity can and eventually will know the as-yet unknown/unknowable. For the adherents, there is no unknowable, given enough time (modern tower of Babel?) In other words, Science is something in which people can put their faith, and this is really just faith in human intellect, or humanity (or, faith in the products of human intellect and endeavor).

This describes something of a belief system.

Nope. The scientific process is very clear about the unknowables. Among them is God, because science deals with the natural universe and does not have the tools to deal with the supernatural.

The way you twist things, language could be a 'belief' system in that we believe we can communicate with it. That's just silly.
Creator is not capitalized and your belief doesn't make it true. You should not speak here.

context: Who knew there was a planetary nebula just the other side of the moon!

replies.context: Huh?  Just the other side of the moon?  The moon is not stationary.  What's on the "other side" of the moon depends on where the moon happens to be at the time.
Nothing is stationary, and you can only see the past.

Some things are stationary relative to others.  When I look out my living room window, I can't see what's on the other side (behind) the house across the street.

But "a planetary nebula just the other side of the moon" makes no sense.
I was making fun of the artist's rendering, since no matter what direction or when, you will not see that in the background of the telescope positioned at the Lagrange point.
apparently you don't know about gravitational lensing...

context: So dark that far out in space, and in the shadow of Earth.  Very excited to see the images it takes and transmits back!

replies.context: It's not in the Earth's shadow.  It's not at the L2 Lagrange point, but orbiting around L2, in a plane that's perpendicular to a line passing through the Sun and the Earth.  It needs to receive sunlight to power solar panels.
Ah, thank you for the clarification.   I was not aware of that particularity.  Now it makes sense to me for the need of a solar shield around the mirrors and telescope section.

Escape sunlight?  What are you trying to say?

The JTW telescope will always be in sunlight. Despite this fact, nasa must uphold their “blackness of space” lie (as we all know, astronauts cannot see stars in space, not even one). 

This blurred ‘selfie’ adheres to NASA’s fake propaganda.

As we all know, the JWST is thoroughly shielded from sunlight (including light reflected from the Earth and Moon), but that's only to keep its temperature down.

Astronauts often can't see stars, because human eyes naturally adjust to see the brightly lit objects around them.  The telescope, unlike a human eye, is narrowly focused in a particular direction, and would not be seeing any nearby brightly lit objects if they were there.

Let me remind you that while Mike Collins was 'piloting' the command module whilst 'orbiting' the moon several times, he was required to navigate by the stars. Yet during the most extraordinary journey man has ever made into space, he clearly stated in the post-landing press conference that "I don't remember seeing any".

If one were in space facing in the opposite direction of the sun, or within the shadow side of the earth or dark side of the moon, the stars would be brilliant.

Armstrong said "I don’t recall, during the period of time that we were photographing the solar corona, what stars we could see."  Collins then added: "I don’t remember seeing any."

He was talking about a particular moment in time, while they were taking pictures of the solar corona (which was before reaching lunar orbit on the way to the moon).
